content: E.g., Zulip archives are publicly available, and we can have legal problems if they contain links to sci-hub etc.

Yury G. Kudryashov said:

E.g., Zulip archives are publicly available, and we can have legal problems if they contain links to sci-hub etc.

That's a good point.
I expected this kind of response. But I wanted to check just in case to make sure not to put the Zulip server in hot water.
Patrick Johnson has marked this topic as resolved.

Yury G. Kudryashov said:

Note that in some cases you can be prosecuted for violating, e.g., US copyright law even if the violation took place outside of the US.

As a side note, the jurisdiction systems in more than 40 countries in the world do not recognize any kind of copyright law whatsoever and have no established extradition contract with the government of the united states. And besides that many people use VPN anyway. So the definition of "violating copyright law" is very disputable, both from the moral and from the legal point of view.
You can say what you like but it won't stand up in court and it may cause other people a whole lot of trouble
Note that Zulip mods do have the ability to delete messages, so if someone posted something illegal we would certainly remove it. But please don't

Kevin Buzzard said:

I think the question is about Zulip not mathlib. I wouldn't go around posting illegal links to copyright material if I were you. This is a serious research forum.

Kevin Buzzard said:

You can say what you like but it won't stand up in court

It can stand can up in court if you live in one of those countries that doesn't care. Hence why, for example, Kim Dotcom moved to New Zealand. :stuck_out_tongue_wink:

My point is that if someone does something stupid here then who cares where they live, Zulip lives in America and Zulip might be inconvenienced and this is not at all what we want. I think the sooner this conversation dies the better, I don't care how many amateur lawyers we have out there.
